snippet: Tariq al-Hashimi, the Iraqi vice president accused of commanding sectarian death squads, was sentenced hours after a wave of attacks that claimed at least 100 lives.
abstract: Tariq al-Hashimi, the vice president of Iraq and prominent Sunni Muslim, is convicted of murder and sentenced to death in a trial conducted in absentia; verdict coincides with a wave of bombings and insurgent attacks that claimed at least 100 lives and threatens sense of normalcy that had emerged earlier in the summer; Sunni leaders who support Hashimi, respond angrily to the court’s action, accusing the Shiite-led government of trying to sideline them from a power-sharing arrangement.

byline.original: By OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
byline.contributor: Omar al-Jawoshy reported from Baghdad, and Michael Schwirtz from New York. Duraid Adnan contributed reporting from Baghdad.

lead_paragraph: Tariq al-Hashimi, the Iraqi vice president accused of commanding sectarian death squads, was sentenced hours after a wave of attacks that claimed at least 100 lives.

headline.seo: Iraq Vice President Sentenced to Death on Day of Violence
headline.main: Death Sentence for a Top Iraqi Leader in a Day of Bloodshed
headline.print_headline: Vice President Of Iraq Is Given Death Sentence
